And you know spoonerisms, where you interchange the initial consonant sounds of two words to get two new words.
For example, if you spoonerize right lane, you get light rain.

SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.
Today, the State Department admitted that employees had snooped into the files of all the presidential candidates, including Hillary Clinton and John McCain.
And that was a day after disclosing that three contract employees had tried to peek into the electronic passport records of Barack Obama.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice apologized today for the incidents, and Barack Obama said that he thinks the Congress should investigate the State Department snooping.
The unauthorized access was uncovered, and it's interesting in this case, by automatic security systems that monitor access to the files of very prominent individuals.
But what if you're not one of those?
What if you're like the rest of us?
Our private - we have data files and government files, we have data in bank records.
What about the digital footprint?

The information about yourself or your habits, information about all of our personal lives that we leave behind in cyberspace as we move about, you know, as we go from place to place online, we make purchases, we explore the Web.
How much privacy do we have?
How much should we expect?

Well, joining me to talk about this are my next two guests, Daniel Weitzner is the W3C Technology and Society Policy director, and the co-director of the MIT CSAIL Decentralized Information Group at MIT.
He joins us from our NPR studios in Washington.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks very much.
: You're welcome.
Alessandro Acquisti is an assistant professor of information technology and public policy at the H.
John Heinz III School of Public Policy and Management.
That's at Carnegie Mellon University.
And the co-editor of the ""Digital Privacy: Theory, Technologies, and Practices."" He joins us from Carnegie Mellon campus.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Thank you for having me.
: Let me ask you first, Dr. Acquisti, were you - what's your reaction to the announcements from the State Department about the snooping there?
Well, sadly, I'm not surprised.
And it's a sad event, but it's just one of many episodes of privacy invasions we have been observing in the news recently or in past months and years.
As you observe a few seconds ago, what is important to note is that, yes, this particular event came to be known because the victims were famous people.
But how many events are happening like that and we don't know about, gives this issue concern?
: Dan Weitzner, do you agree?

I do, and I think the good news in a way and the lesson we should learn is that there are probably a lot of things that we could be doing on a broader basis across the Web, across all different kinds of environments that hold sensitive information about us.
There are a lot more things we could do to hold those institutions accountable and to give people a real sense that the privacy that they expect, you ask the question about expectations...
: Mm-hmm.
: Such as?
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm Linda Wertheimer.
In Somalia, there's more street fighting today in the capital, Mogadishu.
The battles come the day after Islamic militants stormed a seaside hotel, killing 32 people, including six members of parliament.
The hotel attack underscored the ability of insurgents to attack at will, even in the very limited territory the government theoretically controls.
To tell us more, we turn to Jeffrey Gettleman of the New York Times, who recently visited Somalia.
He joined us on the line from his base in Nairobi, Kenya.ï¿½
Good morning, Jeffrey Gettleman.
Good morning.
First of all, could you tell us what happened to the gunmen?
It's not clear exactly what happened to all the gunmen.
From what we've heard, there was a group of about three to five insurgents who showed up at the gates of the hotel.
And they were wearing government military uniforms, which confused the guards at the hotel, who then opened the gate and these guys stormed in.
They immediately started shooting everyone in sight.
And then two of them were wearing suicide vests, and they blew themselves up.
Why was this hotel a target of the attack, do you think?
I think it was a target because it was a well-known hotel among government officials.
There's only a few places that are safe enough for anybody to stay in in central Mogadishu.

However, as we saw, the government is feckless to protect its own people, even in a hotel that's less than a mile away from the presidential palace, which is probably the most secure spot in the country.
How much territory does the government actually control?
Well, Somalia's a country the size of Texas.
And the zone of government control is down to a few neighborhoods, maybe a couple miles in total.
The rest of the country is split up between clan militias, a few semi-autonomous regional governments, and Islamic insurgents who control the vast portion of south central Somalia.
Now, earlier this year the government had pledged to sweep the militants out of the capital and expand its zone of control.
Why hasn't that happened?
That's what we're all wondering about.
I went to Mogadishu in March, and there was a lot of talk that the government was about to sweep across the capital and take back its territory.
But that never happened.
I think one reason why is there's been a number of defections and there's a lot of bickering and in-fighting among the leaders in the transitional government.
And until they solve that, they can't really pull together and fight as one.
